title-group.article-title: Continuum Damage-Healing Mechanics with Introduction to New Healing Variables

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, USA
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, USA
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, Southern University, Baton Rouge, LA 70813, USA

abstract.p: In this study, damage and healing mechanisms are discussed in detail with special emphasis given on two new healing variables. They are introduced in terms of healing variable based on area and healing variable based on elastic stiffness. The main objective of the introduced healing variables is to formulate the mechanical behavior of the self-healing materials and compensate the lack of physically consistent healing variables. Different healing mechanisms, existing in current self-healing systems, are characterized and for a uniaxial case of loading and isotropic material, the scalar healing variables are proposed. The performance of these new healing variables is examined for different damage-healing processes as well as coupled and uncoupled healing systems. The state of damage and healing is assumed to be isotropic for both damaged and healed states. The results show consistency with the basic concepts of the continuum damage mechanics in which introduced healing variables facilitate the self-healing materials characterization.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Self-healing of damage has been increasingly becoming a topic of intensive research recently. The current self-healing systems can be fundamentally divided into two groups: one is a coupled system or active or autonomous system in which damaging triggers self-healing; another is a de-coupled system or passive system where healing occurs after damaging is identified by external detection. Typical coupled systems include healing by microcapsules (White et al., 2001), hollow fibers (Pang and Bond, 2005), microvascular system (Toohey et al., 2007), etc. Typical de-coupled systems include healing by incorporating thermoplastic particles (Zako and Takano, 1999), employing thermally reversible covalent bond (Liu and Chen, 2007), using ionomers (Varley and van der Zwaag, 2008), utilizing confined shape recovery of shape memory polymers (Li and John, 2008; John and Li, 2010; Nji and Li, 2010a), and implementing a biomimic two-step close-then-heal (CTH) system (Li and Nettles, 2010; Li and Uppu, 2010). While the coupled systems, including some de-coupled systems such as incorporation of thermoplastic particles, are effective in self-healing micro-length damage, some of the de-coupled systems, such as confined shape recovery and two-step CTH systems, are designed to heal large, structural-length scale damage (Li and Uppu, 2010; Nji and Li, 2010b).

Constitutive models for healing mainly follow a phenomenological approach to analyze healing process such as geological rock densification (Miao et al., 1995) or simple models for bone remodeling or wound skin regeneration in a biological scheme (Adam, 1999; Simpson et al., 2000). A number of thermodynamic-based continuum damage-healing formulations are proposed in the literature (Miao et al., 1995; Barbero et al., 2005), but due to the difficulties in the experimental aspect, mechanical response modeling of self-healing materials is still under progress.

Material models are proposed by many researchers using elastoplasticity (Chaboche, 1991; Voyiadjis and Thiagarajan, 1995), elasto-viscoplasticity (Chaboche, 1997), continuum damage mechanics (CDM; Kachanov, 1958; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009), and coupled elastoplastic damage (Lemaitre, 1985; Thiagarajan and Voyiadjis, 2000; Al-Rub and Voyiadjis, 2009; Chow and Jie, 2009; Ju et al., 2009; Ju and Yanase, 2009; Voyiadjis et al., 2009) during the past decades. In the case of damage mechanics, the damage variable (or tensor) represents the average material degradation. The damage variable represents the various types of damage at the micro-scale level, like micro-cracks, voids, and micro-cavities (Lubarda and Krajcinovic, 1993; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009). Two independent damage variables are required to describe accurately the case of isotropic damage (Cauvin and Testa, 1999), but it has been argued (Lemaitre, 1984) that the assumption of isotropic damage gives sufficient accuracy to predict the load-carrying capacity, the number of cycles, or the time to local failure in structural components.

In CDM, the concept of representative volume element (RVE) is used, while the discontinuities such as micro-cracks and voids are not considered within the RVE. The concept of macroscopic internal variables is used to lump the effect of all damages and in this way, a thermodynamic consistent formulation is obtained (Hansen and Schreyer, 1994; Miao et al., 1995; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006, 2009; Voyiadjis et al., 2010).

To formulate the healing process, the nature of the healing system should be defined that is a function of many parameters according to the specific healing method which is used. Types of damages and types of constituent material are other important factors during this analysis. In summary, one may mention self-healing system proposed by White et al. (2001) which incorporates microencapsulated healing agent inside the polymeric composites. Solidification of the healing agent within the microcracks or nucleated voids contributes to heal the damages. In this system, damaging (crack propagation) fractures the microcapsules and triggers the healing process so that damaging and healing are coupled. Another system is a two-step CTH system proposed by Li and Nettles (2010) and detailed by Li and Uppu (2010), which mimics the self-healing process of biological systems such as self-healing of human skin. In this system, the confined shape recovery of shape memory polymer is used to narrow or close crack and thermoplastic particle is used for achieving molecular-length scale healing. Through proper training or programming, the shape memory functionality can be utilized to close structural-length scale damage (crack) such as impact damage. This is advantageous over the coupled systems as the coupled systems can only heal micro-length scale damage. However, the healing process is not triggered autonomously. Some human interventions such as identification of damage by external detection and external heating are needed. Therefore, this CTH system belongs to de-coupled or passive healing system.

No matter coupled or de-coupled healing systems, healing can be described in the framework of CDM. This is because healing causes a reduction of the volume of damage and an increase in the stiffness of the material. In order to keep generality, in this research, general physical meaning of the damage and healing processes for the uniaxial case is considered without targeting any specific healing system or any specific material or damage type. The damaged and healed configurations are assumed to be isotropic and no anisotropy has been considered for the virgin material. The proposed healing variables are capturing the healing effect by two distinctive measurement methods that are addressed by direct and indirect methods here. In the direct method, the healing process is observed by the measurement of the effective cross-section changes after the healing, while the indirect method captures elastic stiffness changes in order to calibrate the healing. The relationships between classical damage variables with these new healing variables are derived here to facilitate damage and healing measurements in a self-healing system.

The aim of this study is to introduce new physical-based healing variables to provide a tool for modeling the mechanical responses of self-healing materials. The final goal of this research is to fully establish self-healing material responses under different loading conditions. The basic concept of CDM is revised herein to capture the role of the healing process.

sec.title: SCALAR HEALING VARIABLES
sec.p: In this section, the concept of effective and real configurations in the case of damage-healing is introduced and two new healing variables are formulated based on basic concepts of CDM. The major advantage of CDM is that it utilizes a continuous damage variable in the process zone. Kachanov (1958) was the first to introduce such a continuous variable related to the density of defects and later it has been used widely by many researchers such as Voyiadjis and Kattan (2006, 2009, 2010). Further damage variables have been introduced such as changes in the elastic constants due to damage mechanism (Kachanov, 1958; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009, 2010), or surface energy change in order to describe the material deterioration (Hansen and Schreyer, 1994).

At first, a scalar healing variable for the uniaxial healing process is investigated in order to propose a direct method to capture the healing effect. The same approach introduced by Kachanov (1958) for the damage measurement is followed here to formulate a scalar healing variable to measure the changes in density of defects. For this purpose, the concept of effective configuration, in the framework of CDM, is modified here to capture the effect of healing.

In CDM framework, the initial undeformed and undamaged configuration of the body is shown by C0, and the damaged and deformed configuration is represented by C. The effective configuration is a fictitious state where all damages including microcracks and voids have been removed from the deformed body and it is shown by C¯. In Figure 1, these configurations are depicted schematically. For the case of isotropic damage and using the basic concept of the effective state, the damage variable is defined as a scalar in the following manner (Kachanov, 1958): (1) Figure 1.
(a) Initial undeformed and undamaged configuration: C0, (b) damaged and deformed configuration: C, and (c) effective fictitious undamaged and deformed configuration: C¯.

To define the scalar healing variable, three new configurations are defined below. The fictitious state of fully damaged and deformed configuration Cd, which is obtained by subtracting the fictitious undamaged and deformed cross-section A¯ in the configuration C¯ from the total cross-section A in the configuration C as follows: (2) where Ad is the total damaged cross-section (removed area due to damage). The healing process is assumed to act only on the pure damaged cross-section Ad, and then the fictitious healed and deformed configuration Ch is defined by removing some portion of damages from Ad as shown in Figure 2. Then, the scalar healing variable is defined as follows: (3) where Ah is the healed portion of the cross-section Ad. The case of h = 1 corresponds to zero percent healing of the damaged area (Ah=0), and h = 0 relates to 100% healing of the damaged area (A†h=A†d). Figure 2.
(a) Fictitious total removed area due to damage: Cd and (b) fictitious healed and damaged configuration: Ch.

Finally, the effective fictitious fully healed and deformed configuration C¯h is obtained by removing all the remaining damages from Ch, as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
(a) Fictitious healed and deformed configuration: Ch and (b) effective fictitious fully healed and deformed configuration: C¯h.

According to the basic concept of effective configuration, the damaged area does not sustain load. However, after healing the healed cross-section Ah can carry load T″ as shown in Figures 2 and 3. The cross-section of the hypothetical healed configuration C¯healed is assumed to be the summation of the cross-section of the effective fictitious healed and deformed configuration C¯h and the cross-section of the effective fictitious undamaged and deformed configuration C¯, as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
(a) Virgin material, (b) damaged and deformed configuration: C, (c) and hypothetical healed configuration: C¯heated.
The necessary transformation equation for stresses between C¯healed and C is derived by applying the equilibrium on the healed and damaged states as follows: (4)

In order to compute transformation relation between damaged–healed elastic modulus E(φ,h) and the effective fictitious elastic modulus E¯ in this case, certain assumptions regarding the strains in the two configurations are required. Accordingly, one of the following two hypotheses is followed in the field of damage mechanics:
Hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence: in this case, the strains in both configurations are assumed to be the same and ε=ε¯.
Hypothesis of elastic strain energy equivalence: in this case, elastic strain energy in both cases is assumed to be equivalent.

While both of these hypotheses are being used by researchers in the field of damage mechanics, it is believed that the hypothesis of elastic energy equivalence is more general since it is based on an energy formation. In the following for completeness, both hypotheses are used to derive the transformation relations. However, the hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence is utilized to derive the evolutions laws for damage and healing processes in section ‘Damage and healing evolution equations.’

sec.title: Hypothesis of Elastic Strain Equivalence for Damage Variable ϕ and Healing Variable h
sec.p: The former approach is first used in order to derive the transformation laws between the effective configuration C¯healed and the damaged–healed configuration C. This is the hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence which is stated as follows: (5)

Using the elastic constitutive equation for both the effective configuration C¯healed and the damaged–healed configuration C along with Equation (4), the transformation equation for elasticity modulus between these configurations is computed as follows: (6) where Eh(φ,h) indicates to the damaged and healed elastic modulus and E¯ is the modulus of elasticity for the virgin material. When there is no healing process h = 1, and Equation (6) results in the classical relation: Eh(φ,h=1)=E¯(1-φ) (Kachanov, 1958; Lemaitre and Chaboche, 1990; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006).

sec.title: Hypothesis of Elastic Energy Equivalence for Damage Variable ϕ and Healing Variable h
sec.p: As an alternative approach to deriving the transformation rule of Equation (6), one may use the hypothesis of elastic strain energy equivalence between the effective configuration C¯healed and the real damaged–healed configuration C in order to derive the elastic modulus relation between these two states as follows: (7)
Substituting σ¯ from Equation (4) into Equation (7) results in the relation between the elastic modulus in the two configurations: (8)

The state of 100% healing yields: Eh(φ,h=0)=E¯, and the corresponding elastic modulus is fully recovered after the healing process. In the case when there is no healing process, Equation (8) results in Eh(φ,h=1)=E¯(1-φ)2 which shows consistency with the classical result obtained from the CDM (Kachanov, 1958; Lemaitre and Chaboche, 1990; Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006, 2009). Finally, there are two options to choose from for the transformation laws those are: Equation (6) resulting from the hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence, and Equation (8) which is a direct result from utilizing the hypothesis of elastic energy equivalence. In the following derivation in section ‘Damage and healing evolution equations,’ the hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence is utilized.

Accordingly, the damage parameters based on the area reduction are hard to calibrate in practical applications. The measurement of the cross-section area reduction due to damage or cross-section area increase due to healing involves precise measurement of micro-cracks and micro-voids which is hard to implement and requires advanced mathematical and mapping techniques. In order to facilitate the damage and healing measurement, an indirect measurement method for the damage, proposed by Lemaitre and Dufailly (1987), is modified here to facilitate the damage and healing measurements. This new healing variable for the uniaxial case of healing is introduced based on the elastic modulus changes. The formulation for this healing variable follows the same trend as the scalar damage variable introduced by Voyiadjis and Kattan (2010). The scalar damage variable l measures the elastic modulus changes during a uniaxial damaging process as follows (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009, 2010): (9)

Consequently, another scalar healing variable h' can be defined to measure the change in the elastic modulus during the healing process, as follows: (10) where E¯ is the elastic modulus for a virgin material, Ed(l) the damaged elastic modulus in the damaged and deformed configuration C, and Eh(l,h') the elastic modulus in the healed and deformed configuration Ch. The relation between the three moduli is as follows: (11)
To obtain the transformation equation between the effective and healed elastic moduli, one may substitute Ed(l) from Equation (9) into Equation (10) as follows: (12)

Equation (12) indicates h'=0 corresponds to zero percent healing and results in Eh(l,h'=0)=Ed(l)=E¯/(1+l) which is consistent with the result of pure damage without healing (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2010). By setting Eh(l,h'=l)=E¯, the upper bound for h' is obtained as h'=l. Then, this healing variable can change in the range between 0≤h'≤l which shows consistency with the general concept of healing. In the following one more time for the sake of completeness, the transformation laws are derived for both cases of elastic strain equivalence and elastic energy equivalence. In section ‘Damage and healing evolution equations,’ the elastic strain equivalence is chosen to derive the evolution laws of the damage and healing processes.

sec.title: Hypothesis of Elastic Strain Equivalence for Damage Variable l and Healing Variable h′
sec.p: The former approach to derive the transformation law for stresses is to use the hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence between the two configurations C¯healed and C. Using Equation (5) results in the following transformation law: (13)

In order to obtain a relation between the damage variable l, the healing variable h', the damage variable φ, and the healing variable h for the case of elastic strain equivalence, one may assume that the damaged and healed moduli for each configuration are the same: (14)
Equation (14) shows the relationship between the classical damage variables φ and l with two new healing variables h and h' when the hypothesis of elastic strain equivalence is applied.

sec.title: Hypothesis of Elastic Energy Equivalence
sec.p: The stress transformation between the damaged state C and the hypothetical healed states C¯healed is obtained through the hypothesis of elastic strain energy equivalence equation (7) as follows: (15) where σ¯ is the healed stress in the healed configuration and stress σ is in the damaged configuration.

Next, in order to derive the relation between the damage variables l and φ and the healing variables h and h' in the case of elastic energy equivalence, one may substitute E¯ from Equation (12) into Equation (8) to obtain: (16)

The relationship between the classical damage variables φ and l is shown in Equation (16) with new healing variables h and h', when the hypothesis of elastic strain energy is utilized. It is obvious that in the formulation of a continuum damage-healing mechanics, only one of these two hypotheses can be applied and only one of the two Equations (16) and (14) can exist in the formulation. If the healing is eliminated from the system it means that h'=0, and h = 1 and Equation (16) reduces to: (17) which is consistent with the result published before on this topic (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009). Substituting Equation (17) into Equation (16) results in: (18)
If one uses φ instead of l, then the above relation becomes: (19)
Note that Equations (18) and (19) are special cases of Equation (16).

sec.title: DAMAGE AND HEALING EVOLUTION EQUATIONS
sec.p: The energy considerations concept is adopted here to derive the evolution equations of the damage and healing variables for an uncoupled damage–healing process. It is assumed that the material obeys the damage criterion proposed by Lee et al. (1985). It is a scalar function of gd and a generalized thermodynamic force yd that corresponds to damage variable. In order to incorporate the healing effect, one may define a similar healing criterion which is a scalar function of gh and a generalized conjugated thermodynamic force yh. These two criteria are defined as follows: (20) (21) where Ld(sd) is a damage-strengthening parameter which is a function of the ‘overall’ damage parameter sd, and Lh(sh) the strengthening effects for the healing, and sh the ‘overall’ healing parameter. Two sets of evolution equation are derived here based on the proposed damage and healing variables.

sec.title: Evolution Laws Based on the Damage Variable φ and the Healing Variable h
sec.p: Substituting the elastic stiffness from Equation (8) into Equation (7) results in following expression for the elastic strain energy in the damaged–healed configuration: (22)
Differentiating Equation (22) results in: (23)
The generalized conjugated thermodynamic forces corresponding to damage and healing processes are then defined as follows: (24) (25)
In order to derive the normality rule regarding damage and healing process, one may use the power of dissipation definition as follows: (26)

The problem is reduced to extremize the energy dissipation function Π while it is subjected to the constraint Equations (20) and (21). Incorporating Lagrange multipliers results in the following functional, to be minimized: (27)
Substituting Equations (20), (21), and (26) into Equation (27) yields: (28)
Applying the stationary conditions of ∂Ψ∂yd=0, ∂Ψ∂yh=0, ∂Ψ∂Ld=0, and ∂Ψ∂Lh=0, Equation (28) results in the following relations: (29) (30) (31) (32)

Equations (29) and (30) are evolution equations for damage and healing variables and Equations (31) and (32) are showing the relation between damage and healing variables and their corresponding multipliers. To obtain damage and healing variables, consistency conditions dgd=0 and dgh=0 are applied as follows: (33) (34)
Making use of Equations (20), (21), (31), and (32) and using dLd=dsd(∂Ld∂sd) and dLh=dsh(∂Lh∂sh) into Equations (33) and (34) result in: (35) (36)
To investigate the strain-damage and strain-healing relations, one may differentiate from Equations (24) and (25) as follows: (37) (38)
Substituting Equations (35) and (36) into Equations (29) and (30) yields the evolution equations in terms of conjugated forces and strengthening functions as follows: (39) (40)
Making use of Equations (24), (25), (37), and (38) into Equations (39) and (40) result in the strain-damage and strain-healing relations as follows: (41) (42)
In the case of damage without healing, by plugging h = 1 and dh=0, Equation (41) results in: (43)

Equation (43) shows consistency with the fundamental damage mechanics relationship between the damage and the strain (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2006, 2009). By simple change of variables x=h(1-hφ)ε2, Equation (41) reduces to: (44)

One may consider a linear function of the form Ld=csd+d, where c and d are constants, and then Equation (44) can be solved as follows: (45) where h0 is the initial damage value. In the similar way, Equation (42) is solved by the change of variables y=φ(1-hφ)ε2 and the linear function assumption of the form Lh=c'Sh+d', where c' and d' are constants. The resulting relation is as follows: (46) where h0 is the initial value of healing variable. Equations (45) and (46) are strain-damage and strain-healing relations for the damage variable φ and the healing variable h, respectively.

sec.title: Evolution Laws Based on the Damage Variable l and the Healing Variable h
sec.p: Substituting the elastic stiffness from Equation (10) into Equation (7) results in following expression for the elastic strain energy in the damaged–healed configuration: (47)
Differentiating Equation (47) results in: (48)
The generalized conjugated thermodynamic forces corresponding to damage yd=∂U∂l and healing yh=∂U∂h' processes are then defined as follows: (49) (50)
To investigate the strain-damage and strain-healing relations, one may differentiate from Equations (49) and (50) as follows: (51) (52)
Equations (39) and (40) are modified for the damage variable l and healing variable h' as follows: (53) (54)
Substituting Equations (49)–(52) into Equations (53) and (54) results in: (55) (56)
Equations (55) and (56) represent the strain-damage and healing–damage relationships for the damage variable l and the healing variable h', respectively.

sec.title: COUPLED AND UNCOUPLED HEALING PROCESSES WITH THE DAMAGE PROCESS
sec.p: The introduced new healing variables can capture the coupled continuum damage-healing processes as well as the de-coupled continuum damage and healing processes. This concept is interesting because some of the present self-healing systems are either coupled or de-coupled.

These healing variables can measure the healing effect while both healing and damaging processes are active (coupled continuum damage-healing process), such as the microencapsulated self-healing systems proposed by White et al. (2001). In these systems, when damage reaches a certain value, the microcapsules are cracked and the healing agent is released to heal the microcracks and voids. One may consider such a system as a coupled damage–healing system where damage and healing processes are concurrently activated. Coupled systems may use hollow fibers (Pang and Bond, 2005), and microvascular system (Toohey et al., 2007), etc.

Besides, the introduced healing variables can measure healing and damaging effects separately, when only one of these processes is active (de-coupled continuum damage-healing process). The de-coupled systems require additional processes to accomplish the healing process, such as heating. Systems incorporating thermoplastic particles (Zako and Takano, 1999), employing thermally reversible covalent bond (Liu and Chen, 2007), using ionomers (Varley and van der Zwaag, 2008), utilizing confined shape recovery of shape memory polymers (Li and John, 2008; John and Li, 2010; Nji and Li, 2010a), and implementing a biomimic two-step CTH system (Li and Nettles, 2010; Li and Uppu, 2010) are examples of these uncoupled systems. The de-coupled continuum damage and healing mechanism is shown schematically in Figure 5. Point A shows the starting point of the unloading path and the material in this point contains both plastic deformation and damages such as microcracks and voids. Point B indicates a healing process, and the reloading path starts at point B. The healed material shows a higher elastic modulus in this case. Figure 5.
Schematic representation of uncoupled damage and healing processes.

sec.title: RESULT AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
The performance of the new introduced uniaxial healing variables is evaluated here for both the coupled and the uncoupled damage–healing processes. In the case of elastic strain energy equivalence, the relation between the damage variables and the healing variables is introduced in Equation (16). The effect of healing is studied in Figure 6. The state of fully damaged configuration is obtained by setting the healing variables in such a way to eliminate the healing effect (h = 1, h'=0). The effect of healing parameter h is then evaluated for three different healing values such as: h = 0.8, 05, and 0.3, and the healing variable h' is kept zero. It is seen that the valid ranges for the damage variable φ when the damage variable l varies in the range 0<l<1 is 0≤φ≤0.293. Consequently, the limiting maximum value for φ based on the definition of the stiffness reduction of l is 0.293 (Voyiadjis and Kattan, 2009). However, in the case of the healed configuration, this limiting value is increased and the material can sustain more damage based on the definition of φ with respect to the unhealed material. Figure 6.
Effect of healing variable h on damage parameters φ and l.

In the case of the coupled damage-healing process, one may use the physical relation between the damage and healing processes or introduce an empirical relation to define the governing relation between the healing and damage variables.

For instance, in the case of self-healing materials containing microencapsulated healing agent, one may find a relation between the introduced damage into the system and the diffused healing agent into the micro-cracks. Here, an empirical function is introduced which relates the damage variable l to the healing variable h' as follows: (57) where α and β are the two material-dependent constants which may represent the physical characterization and dispersion of microcapsules and diffusion and effectiveness of the healing agent. Equation (57) is depicted in Figure 7. The healing is assumed to recover all damages at the initial stages of the damage process, and with increasing the amount of the introduced damage into the system the effectiveness of the healing process is reduced. Figure 7.
Empirical relation between damage variable l and healing variable h' in a coupled damage-healing process.

This empirical relation is now introduced into the system and the coupled damage-healing process is evaluated. In the case of elastic strain energy equivalence and making use of Equation (16), the effect of the healing process h'on the damage variable φ is depicted in Figure 8, while the healing variable h is set to be 1 which means this healing variable is deactivated. The damaged configuration and the two coupled damage-healing configurations are shown in Figure 8. Both healing processes show full recovery of the damage variable φ at the initial damage process and both of these healing processes show less damage value for φ at the point l = 1. Figure 8.
Effect of healing variable h' in a coupled damage-healing process on damage variable φ.

The effect of the healing variable h' in the case of elastic strain energy equivalence in a coupled damage–healing process on the stress ratio σσ¯ (stress ratio between damaged and effective configuration) is depicted in Figure 9. Equation (15) is used and both healed configurations show an initial nondamaged response. After a certain limit of damage, they show higher stress ratios which is an indication of a strengthened material where damaged stress is closer to the effective nondamaged configuration. Figure 9.
Effect of healing variable h' in a coupled damage-healing process on stress ratio between damaged and effective configurations.

One may introduce the governing Equation (57) into an uncoupled damage–healing process such as self-healing materials which undergo two-step CTH (Li and Uppu, 2010). In Figure 10, this situation is investigated where the material is unloaded and healed at a certain level of damage (l = 0.5). Healing parameters is chosen as α = 0.9 and β = 2, and the material is loaded after healing. As is clearly observed from Figure 10, the damage variable l following the healing process is reduced and the material shows higher resistance to the damage after healing. Figure 10.
Effect of healing variable h' in an uncoupled damage-healing process on stress ratio between damaged and effective configurations.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The mechanics of the damage and healing processes for the uniaxial case of loading is investigated in which different healing strategies are mathematically formulated for self-healing materials. Using CDM framework, two new healing variables for uniaxial case are presented. The concept of effective configuration is modified in order to be able to capture the healing effect. The virgin, damaged, and healed configurations are assumed to be isotropic. The exact relations between the two scalar damage variables and two scalar healing variables are derived for the uniaxial case for both hypotheses of elastic strain equivalence and elastic strain energy equivalence. Using a thermodynamic consistent approach the evolution laws for the damage and healing variables are obtained. The effect of healing on the upper bound of classical damage variable φ is investigated. Moreover, the performance of the introduced healing variables is investigated for the coupled and uncoupled damage–healing processes. The proposed healing variables can describe the healing effect efficiently for both of the coupled and uncoupled damage–healing systems, and they show consistency with the published results on CDM. They can be used in future modeling and experimental works to define the self-healing material mechanical responses under different loading conditions.

fn.p: Figures 1–10 appear in color online: http://ijd.sagepub.com
